title: RADS error or unable to connect to support.riotgames.com
body:
This is typically caused by expired DNS records. Either your PC, router, or ISP's DNS server is caching old records for longer than usually acceptable and this makes it impossible for you to connect to any of our domain names.

**You can help us work with ISP's to solve this issue by doing the following:**

1) Open a command prompt (for windows 7: type cmd in the start search bar and hit enter)
2) Type "ping l3cdn.riotgames.com" without the quotes and hit enter
3) It should return something like:

Pinging l3cdn.riotgames.com [14.200.100.27] with 32 bytes of data:
Reply from 14.200.100.27: bytes=32 time=46ms TTL=56
Reply from 14.200.100.27: bytes=32 time=124ms TTL=56
Reply from 14.200.100.27: bytes=32 time=43ms TTL=56
Reply from 14.200.100.27: bytes=32 time=81ms TTL=56

4) If you do not receive 4 replies, copy the results to a text file and attach them here, or post a screenshot.

5) Attach the following logs from "C:\Riot Games\League of Legends\Logs\Patcher Logs":

- Latest launcher.log
- Latest LoLPatcher.log

There are solutions to the problem, the simplest is to configure your PC or router to use Google DNS. Instructions [here](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues#wq4). Riot Zaps has commented on this thread outlining the steps if you are unable to reach this link.
**However, this is a sub-optimal solution** as you are no longer utilizing your ISP's DNS server and this may affect some of their service features, such as un-metered downloads. We recommend this only as a temporary workaround or for troubleshooting.

Otherwise, if you know how, you can lower the TTL of the DNS records on your router or run a [/flushdns](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues#wq9) on your PC, but these will only work if either of them is the source of the issue respectively.

replies.body: I cant even open the link. It just says This Webpage is not available

I've copied the relevant information from the article above - let us know if this helps with your issue! 

**Windows 8**

* Hit the Windows Key
*  Type "Control Panel"
*  Select "Network and Internet"
*  Select "Network and Sharing Center"
*  Select "Change Adapter Settings" on the navigation bar on the left
*  Right click on your network adapter and select "Properties"
*  Select "Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4)" and open "Properties"
*  Go to the bottom of the menu and change "Obtain DNS server address automatically," to "Use the following DNS server addresses:"
*  Put in the following public DNS servers, one in each empty field:
  * 8.8.8.8 
  * 8.8.4.4
*  Save your changes by selecting "Ok"
*  Close all open web browsers and applications
*  Hit the Windows Key
*  Right click anywhere
*  Click on "All Apps"
*  Right click "Command Prompt" and run as administrator
*  Type ipconfig /flushdns and press Enter.
*  Restart your computer

**Windows 7**

*  Open the Start Menu
*  Open Control Panel
*  Select "Network and Internet"
*  Select "Network and Sharing Center"
*  Select "Change Adapter Settings" on the navigation bar on the left
*  Right click on your network adapter and select "Properties"
*  Select "Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4)" and open Properties
*  Go to the bottom of the menu and change 'Obtain DNS server address automatically,' to 'Use the following DNS server addresses:'
*  Put in the following public DNS servers, one in each empty field:
  * 8.8.8.8 
  * 8.8.4.4
*  Save your changes by selecting "Ok"
*  Close all open web browsers and applications
*  Press the Windows Key
*  In the Search bar type command prompt
*  Right click on the result and select Run as Administrator
*  In the command prompt type ipconfig /flushdns and press Enter.
*  Restart your computer

**Windows XP**

*  Open the Start Menu
*  Open Control Panel
*  Open Network Connections
*  Right click on your network adapter and select "Properties"
*  Select "Internet Protocol (TCP/IP)" and open "Properties"
*  Go to the bottom of the menu and change "Obtain DNS server address automatically,"to "Use the following DNS server addresses:"
*  Put in the following public DNS servers, one in each empty field:
  * 8.8.8.8 
  * 8.8.4.4
*  Save your changes by selecting "Ok"
*  Close all open web browsers and applications
*  Press the Windows Key
*  In the Search bar type command prompt
*  Right click on the result and select Run as Administrator
*  In the command prompt type ipconfig /flushdns and press Enter.
*  Restart your computer
This works as I think the game runs through Google.

Also, IP I got was 50.112.157.128 with Google's DNS.

Image attached.

Hi HORSE OF FORCE, (I'll respect the capitalization)

We're still battling to solve this issue for a few players, at this point theirs may be a different issue.

But would you mind telling me how you resolved this issue for yourself?

Thank you for using the correct capitalisation. Most people just say "Horse" and that really gets under my horse skin.

How I resolved it? Well, I'm not too sure myself, it was over a month ago, and my memory is shockingly bad. It probably involved refresh **everything**, though wait

wait

I'm still getting this problem. It's nothing to do with connecting to the game and logging in, it's the patching. I'm still getting stuck at 32% every time there's a patch out, and the only way around it is to reinstall the entire game.

I just tried pinging l3cdn.riotgames.com (which it says is 184.84.220.114 instead of 14.200.100.27?) again, and this time it worked. 0% loss.

So, in summary, this issue is not resolved for me, but I find that I'm able to circumvent it by **reinstalling the game every time there's a patch.**

Hey Riot Gehirn, I was looking through my board history and saw this comment I made, and was rather unsatisfied with it. There's no real answer here.

The problem has remained persistent, that is, with every patch the patcher will reach 32% and then fail. My most recent test with pinging l3cdn.riotgames.com actually works now, but the patcher is failing in the exact same method (also, it's still going to address 184.84.220.112 instead of 14.200.100.27).

I found out that the patcher is **not** marking the game folder as completely downloaded, thus it then attempts to download the missing files, but the files are already there and it fails. This issue is not isolated to only I. A solution is to manually mark the folder as completely downloaded after the patcher downloads the patch and fails, thus making the next time it boots up it will just work.

It's a tad bit complicated, though, and users shouldn't have to go to such extremes just to tell the patcher it's actually done. If you could fix that behaviour in the patcher, you would solve a lot of people's problems.

Best of luck in bringing attention to this, Riot Gehirn.

I'm sorry I didn't see this reply for so long. :(

You're right, players should not have to reinstall the game or go through the above workaround every time they are required to patch. I'm interested in getting to the root of this problem, I'd like to talk to some other Rioters about why such a workaround would solve this issue and that may lead us somewhere.

Can you describe the workaround in more detail? How do you go about performing: "manually mark the folder as completely downloaded after the patcher downloads the patch and fails"?

I have a tiny bit of coding experience, so I just presumed based on what I was doing that that was what the initial coder intended on doing.

The exact workaround is as follows:
1. A new patch is released. Open the client and download the majority of it. The patcher gets stuck at 32% and spouts out "Unkown Error".

2. Navigate to ...>Riot Games>League of Legends>RADS>projects>lol_air_client>releases> where ... is replaced with your install directory.

3. Create a new, empty file in the current version folder named "S_OK" with no extension. Restart League with admin privileges.
4. The patcher automatically jumps to 32% complete, and scans files for a while. Then it finishes downloading the patches (usually only a few megabytes, since the majority was downloaded beforehand) and 'applies' the patches for the remainder. Usually the remaining 67% is completed *much* faster than the initial 32%.
League works now, but all settings retaining to it as a application are reset, ie. if you set a custom volume for it via Sound Mixer, it will go back to 100%.

I'm still consistently getting this problem whenever a new patch for League is released. What I'm thinking is that, in order to simplify/optimise the process, the patcher will only 'apply' the patches if it reads the "S_OK" file in the directory of the folder it plans to copy the files too. Under normal circumstances, upon completion of downloading the preliminary files it would create the "S_OK" file and then start up the scanner to check it, and then the files would be copied over, but it seems like it's failing to create the "S_OK" file in the first place. I monitored the folder as it was patching and found that the patcher only creates the 'temp' files from the downloading process and not the "S_OK" file, along with any directory architecture required for the files to be transferred. It *may* be a permissions issue, but I find that the exact same behaviour happens if the application is started with admin privileges.

It could be that the patcher was relying on some sort of dependency to create the "S_OK" file, but it's lacking on some systems and hence it brings out an unexpected result. Could it be related to the fact that Microsoft renamed their file explorer (which is the biggest candidate for possible dependencies, as all Windows computers need it to function, much like Internet Explorer) between versions of Windows 7 and Windows 8.

I appreciate you responding to this even after so long. If you need any more information I'll be glad to give it.

Best of luck in finding a fix for it.

Edit: Ok so it just doesn't like back-slashes. What a weird character to exclude.
Thanks a bunch dude, I've passed this along. I'll let you know how we go.
No problem. Hope to hear from you soon.

Hi again HORSE OF FORCE,

I need to gather more info before I can chase this any further. If possible, when you next need to patch (in a couple of days) could you please:

- attempt to patch normally, allowing the issue to occur.
- once the issue occurs open the patcher "Help" window, by clicking the icon shown in the attachment
- select the "Save Logs" option and save the generated folder

- attempt the fix that you've been using to get around the issue
- allow patching to complete successfully
- save the generated logs again, you should now have logs collected for after the issue occurred, and after the issue was fixed.

Once you have both log folders, send them in an email to ocelivereports@riotgames.com

I'll then be able to check these out and see if we can deduce a potential cause.

Alright. I'll have to make a note or something because I'm bound to forget this and just repair anyway. As a back up could you reply to this message so when I check the boards I see that I have to do this while patching please?
Alright!
Change your TCP/IPv4 to 8.8.8.8
I've marked the one that had the patcher fail, just to be sure. Windows update was running as well, but none of those updates were related to network, so it should all be good.

(placeholder)

So apparently the boards has an unknown character limit.
Hi this is my cmd ping thing
and this is my patcher log attachments

Still patiently waiting for any solutions to RADS error. 
I'm wanting to play more Bard but the only place I can do that is at an internet cafe and that is getting pretty costly.

:O!!

THANK YOU RIOT!
It seems patience pays off and the problem is fixed, for me at least. :)

RADS error is usually when your client can't connect to any source of internet, either from being blocked by a firewall or just not having an active connection. What I'm saying is that with a good configuration and fine computer, even if the servers were shutdown, you wouldn't get a RADS error. Anything Riot have done wouldn't have fixed it.

Exactly what happened to supposedly fix your connection?

I really have no idea. Nothing changed on my local computer and nothing changed in local internet/router settings either. I just discovered I regained access to Riot's support and downloads pages. Maybe it was my ISP.

Monkeys must be fiddling with things.

Oh, you also didn't have access to their support page? That was probably the result of your ISP's DNS not having the Riot Games server address in their database.

In layman's terms, it was your internet company that was at fault. They fixed it, not Riot.
It's still fixed, I'm still happy :)

I still have this "RADS Error" thing for the past 2 weeks, decided to reinstall LoL (hopefully it would fix it), but cannot access the download page or the support page to try send a ticket in, been really bored. Tried the 8888 8884 trick and so and so.

The IP I got in cmd was 50.112.145.114

Hi Nyanphy,

If you're still not able to log in, could you please post a couple of other logs here so that our local network engineers can take a look at them?

2) Attach to this post, the latest launcher.log and LoLPatcher.log

This nonsense is happening to me again. Changing my DNS to Google's one gets the game working all good, but it's a small hassle having to change the DNS every time I feel like playing. This seems to be a TPG problem again as other friends of mine on other ISPs have no problems.

Hey I was directed here by Mindstar ( see thread http://boards.oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/help-support-oce/cNhtazmu-can-not-download-league-again ) 
It's been over a week now and I'm pretty disappointed that I still haven't been able to download LoL. 
my results are all on the thread quoted above.

So basically i have made posts on the same issue, and nothing was done and i got no reply from anyone (players or support)

there are a few things you can try that worked for me, they may not work for you and it wasn't until the new update i was constantly looking for a new fix every other day as not one worked twice.

First try resetting your PC. (worked for two of the times i went through this)
second  try resetting your Modem (this worked a couple of times too)
Third try updating your pc drivers (worked for one of the time)
If none of these work their is the directions here
